content.title: Arterial Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (ATOS)
content.definition: Compression of the subclavian artery at the thoracic outlet, typically by a cervical rib or anomalous first rib, causing post-stenotic aneurysm formation, thrombosis, and distal embolization with limb-threatening ischemia. Rarest form of TOS (<1%) but most dangerous.

key_concepts.description: Bony abnormality (cervical rib, abnormal first rib) causes repetitive arterial compression → intimal damage → post-stenotic dilation/aneurysm → thrombus formation → distal embolization
Young adults; slight male predominance (unlike neurogenic); almost always associated with bony abnormality (cervical rib in 80-90%)
Upper extremity ischemia from embolization: cold, painful, pale hand/fingers; digital gangrene; may present with arm claudication; rarely asymptomatic aneurysm
Post-stenotic aneurysm is pathognomonic; prone to thrombus formation and distal embolization; can cause acute hand/finger ischemia
Supraclavicular pulsatile mass (aneurysm); diminished/absent radial pulse with arm elevation; digital ischemia signs; may have bruit
X-ray: cervical rib or first rib anomaly; CTA/MRA: subclavian stenosis, post-stenotic aneurysm, thrombus; angiography with provocative positioning
Unlike neurogenic TOS, arterial TOS with embolization is a vascular emergency; requires urgent evaluation and treatment
Surgical: rib resection (cervical rib and/or first rib) PLUS arterial reconstruction (aneurysm resection with interposition graft or bypass); thrombolysis/embolectomy for distal emboli
Address distal emboli first if acute ischemia (embolectomy/thrombolysis) → then definitive decompression and arterial reconstruction
Excellent outcomes if treated before extensive distal thrombosis; delayed treatment may result in digital amputations despite successful proximal reconstruction

learning_objectives: Define arterial TOS as the rarest but most dangerous TOS form
Understand that cervical rib is almost always present (80-90%)
Know that treatment requires both decompression AND arterial reconstruction
clinical_pearls: ATOS is <1% of TOS but most dangerous
Young patient + cervical rib + digital ischemia = think ATOS
Cervical rib present in 80-90% (unlike neurogenic TOS)
Treatment = rib resection + aneurysm repair (not just decompression)
Address distal emboli FIRST if acute ischemia
common_mistakes: Only doing rib resection without arterial reconstruction
Missing the cervical rib on X-ray
Confusing with primary Raynaud (look for aneurysm/cervical rib)
